subject_as_recorded: Syriac language, Palestinian--Early works to 1800|Religious poetry, Syriac--Early works to 1800|Hymns, Syriac--Early works to 1800|Prayer books--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Syriac--Early works to 1800
physical_description: Extent: 330 leaves : ill. ; 21 x 20 cm
note: Manuscript written on paper in Modern Nesrorian script.|Shelfmark: MS X893 T13|A service book (leaves 1-189) -- a prayer book for the ordinary days of the week.|Anthems for the eve of each month (leaves 190-202) -- written by several Syriac authorities like Rabban Abraham of Seleucia composed in the year 1837 of the Seleucid era (1525-1526). One anthem was written by Mar Gabriel, nephew of the preceding, who wrote them in the convent of Mar Aujen (Eugenius) in the year 1900 of the Seleucid era (1598-1599). Other anthems were written by ʻAbdIsho of Gazarta.|Anthems of the martyrs (leaves 203-257) - twelve anthems for the evening and morning services of festival days.|Chronology (278-296) - a treatise dealing with chronology, especially how to determine the dates of the church year by letters character.|Grammatical treatse (297-329) - a grammatical treatise dealing with the points used in Syriac for vowel signs and for marking the accent wtc., by Joseph Bishop of Merda (Mardin).

holding_institution_as_recorded: Columbia University Rare Book & Manuscript Library
holding_institution_shelfmark: Ms Coll Dutch Jewish Archive, Box 1
subject_as_recorded: Ashkenazim--Netherlands--Amsterdam--History--18th century--Sources|Sephardim--Netherlands--Amsterdam--History--18th century--Sources|Religious institutions--Netherlands--Amsterdam--Early works to 1800|Amsterdam (Netherlands)--Religious life and customs--Early works to 1800
note: Letters in Hebrew, German, and Ladino relating to the Jewish community of Amsterdam and other Dutch cities, including five letters sent from the Mahamad of the Portuguese Jewish community of Hamburg to its Amsterdam counterpart (1643-1670) and nine drafts of letters from the Parnassim of Amsterdam (1765-1795), et al.|Shelfmark: Ms Coll Dutch Jewish Archive, Box 1|The community of Jews of Spanish and Portuguese origin in Hamburg, Germany maintained close ties with its larger and more established sister community in Amsterdam. The documents here present a clear picture of intimate and ongoing relations between the two communities, and of their intense involvement in one another's daily affairs. The Hamburg community sought the advice of its Amsterdam sister regarding important milestones in its public affairs. Among Jews descended from the subjects of the Spanish and Portuguese Expulsions or from Spanish-Portuguese conversos, there was constant interchange between the two cities, in terms of family ties, marriages, trade, and more, and all these various relationships are dealt with in detail in the present documents. Five of the letters were sent from the Mahamad of the Portuguese Jewish community of Hamburg to its Amsterdam counterpart: 1) Letter regarding the Hamburg Portuguese-Jewish community's plans to establish and organize an association, in light of the Amsterdam community's successful efforts to do the same. 1643. 2) A letter with a request for assistance in the matter of a certain individual by the name of Isaac Penso, accused of murder and wanted by the authorities, who was blackmailing the Hamburg community. 1658. 3) A letter with regard to the "Beth Din" (religious tribunal) constituted to adjudicate on a matter pertaining to the financial affairs of Dr. Benjamin Musaphia; the litigant was taking issue with the makeup of the tribunal, and the Mahamad was seeking assistance in its efforts to persuade him to come to an understanding in this matter. 1658. 4) Thank-you letter expressing gratitude for efforts to persuade one Isaac Calvo to desist from returning to Hamburg. 1670. 5) Letter of recommendation to the Mahamad of the Amsterdam community in the matter of Rabbi Jacob Sasportas who was leaving Hamburg and heading to the Levant on account of financial difficulties, and was in need of assistance. 1670. The five additional documents are personal letters and legal documents dealing with trade, marriage, and other affairs: 6) Document wherein the undersigned testify that Rohiel Jesurum (Reuel Jesurun) of Hamburg has, in their presence, appointed his daughter, the wife of Moses Gideon Abudiente, as his heiress. 1664. 7) Letter dealing with the matter of the marriage of Abraham Abendana de Brito to Hannah Nahamias de Castro. Signed by Dr. Isaac Pimental and Joseph Abendana, uncles of the bridegroom's father, appointed by the father to mediate between him and the father of the bride; David De Nahamias, father of the bride; and Dr. Baruch (Benedict) Nahamias. 1671. 8) Letter of greetings and congratulations from David Abendana Mendes of Hamburg to his cousin Isaac da Costa of Amsterdam on the occasion of his marriage to Hannah Abendana Nahmias. 1749. Spanish. 9) Contract between Rabbi Solomon Salem and Abraham Jehisquia Bassan, according to which Bassan would become a licensed partner in a matzah-baking business venture accredited by the community, the license to which was entrusted to Salem's son, the minor Isaac Salem, for a period of 10 years. January 7, 1765. 10) Letter from Abraham Curiel Bueno of Maarsen, the Netherlands, to Moses Ricardo of Amsterdam, dealing with an apartment rental. 1787. Enclosed: Two popular poems (a Sephardic Jewish romance and a love poem in Portuguese) handwritten on a folded sheet. Both poems have been documented in Jewish manuscripts miscellanies. In the present version, an additional verse has been added to the poem in Portuguese; this verse is not included in any of the other known sources. [Amsterdam, late 17th century or 18th century].

physical_description: Extent: 199 leaves : paper ; 29 x 19 cm
note: Manuscript written on paper in Yemenite handwriting.|Shelfmark: MS X893 J55|The binding is covered with fragments of Midrash ha-Gadol on Exodus 12.|The Ms. is defective at the beginning, and also at the end. It is very rich in content. In addition to the regular prayers it includes Pirḳe Avot ; Haggada for Passover with a long commentary in Arabic ; the book of Esther , Lamentations and Job ; the Antiochus Scroll in Aramaic ; full collection of Seliḥot ; Ibn Gabirol's Azharot ; the Mishnaic tracts Rosh ha-Shanah,Yoma, Bezah, Sukkah, Pesaḥim ; a discussion on benedictions (berakhot) and other laws, e.g. Terumah, Maʻakeh ; Forms for various documents, e.g. Marriage, Yibbum, Ḥalitsh ; and a treatise on the calendar.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Columbia University Rare Book & Manuscript Library
subject_as_recorded: Death--Religious aspects--Judaism|Burial laws (Jewish law)|Jews--Germany--Altona--History--18th century|Jews--Germany--Hamburg--History--18th century|Manuscripts, Hebrew
physical_description: Extent: 1 volume (8 pages) ; 21 cm
note: Manuscript in Hebrew on paper in square and cursive calligraphic Ashkenazic hand.|Shelfmark: MS General 320|This manuscript includes the regulations of the Ḥevra Kadisha (Jewish Burial Society) of Altona and Hamburg, with a responsum from Chief Rabbi Ezekiel Katzenellenbogen, in five sections: 1. An introduction explaining at which meetings these Takanot were adopted.--2. Records twelve Takanot concerning the workings of the Society. (No. 5: "We shall adhere to the stringent obligation of studying Torah through the night of Shavu'ot and Hoshanah Rabbah.under the penalty of a fine...yet the innocent (i.e., those with a valid excuse) are exempted by the Merciful One.").--3. Records fourteen orders of procedure relating to preparing the deceased on Yom Tov. (No. 2: "If there is a death on Yom Tov, it is prohibited to bury before Hatzot. However, if the deceased is a worthy person, it is permissible to bury him prior to the morning prayers, for his greater honor.")--4. Ten Takanot with obligations to be observed by the shamashim of the Ḥevra. (No. 3: "When a death occurs, the shamash is obligated to immediately inform the gabbai and then the other members of the Ḥevra.").--5. A responsum by the Chief Rabbi of the community, Rabbi Yehezkel Katzenellenbogen (1670-1749) responding to five halachic queries submitted by the Burial Society.|Manuscript in Hebrew on paper; written in square and cursive calligraphic Ashkenazic hand.

subject_as_recorded: Carmi family|Jews--Dietary laws--Early works to 1800|Shehitah--Early works to 1800
physical_description: Extent: Leaves 20a-63b : paper ; 17 x 11 cm
note: Ms. includes a separate leaf of a license to slaughter animals according to ritual. The license was given by Elyaḳim Padovani to Avraham Daṿid Regineni.|Shelfmark: MS X893 H541|Manuscript written on papre in Italian cursive hand.|The compendium is preceded by two introductions by the author's father, Yeshʻaya ben Yosef Karmi. One is dated to 1781, and the other 1785. They are both very laudatory, expressing the father's happiness in the achievements of his son and his hopes for greater success.|Leaf 64a contains a list of five children born to Yedidia Karmi ben Yosef Ḥay Karmi and his wife Grazia Unia from 1758-1767. The list includes the name of the Mohel, Isʹraʼel Benjamin Bassano, and the name of the author's uncles David Ashkenazi of Mantua and Elḥanan David Karmi. Leaf 64b has a list of six names in Italian, apparently of members of the Karmi Family, and the dates (possibly of their birth) from 1762 to 1787.

subject_as_recorded: Jews--Italy--History--18th century|Jews--Italy--History--19th century|Jews--Italy--Livorno--History|Tuscany (Italy)--Commerce--History--18th century|Tuscany (Italy)--Commerce--History--19th century
note: Volume 1: Manuscript ledger of income and expenditure between 1761 and 1786; mainly in Italian, with a few terms in Hebrew, cursive Italian Hebrew script.|Shelfmark: MS General 237|Volume 2:1: Letterbooks with autograph letters from Joseph Franchetti to clients, suppliers, and intermediaries, January 1776-early 1780; mainly in Italian; contemporary stiff cover, parchment binding.|Volume 2:2: Letterbooks with autograph letters from Joseph Franchetti to clients, suppliers, and intermediaries, March 1781-end of 1790; mainly in Italian; contemporary stiff cover, parchment binding.|Volume 3: Manuscript ledger of income and expenditure, April 1795-November 1796; bound in parchment and leather.|Volume 4: Printed appeal, in French, in legal case brought by Franchetti family members against parties in Lyon, France, ca. 1817.|Volume 5:1: Documents relating to the death of Isaac Franchetti, Senior, in Pisa, Italy, April 30, 1832.|Volume 5:2: File of 96 receipts for liquidation payments from Abraham and Isaac Franchetti, Junior, to other family members.|Volume 6: Receipt book for years 1845-1859; bound in parchment.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Columbia University Rare Book & Manuscript Library
subject_as_recorded: Blood accusation--France--Metz--History--17th century|Antisemitism--France--Metz--History--17th century|Jews--Persecutions--France--Metz--History--17th century|Trials (Murder)--France--Metz|Antisemitism|Blood accusation|Jews--Persecutions|Trials (Murder)|France--Metz|1600-1699|Manuscripts, Yiddish
physical_description: Extent: 30 leaves ; 20 x 32 cm
note: Manuscript in Old Yiddish.|Shelfmark: MS General 321|Ink on paper.|Pages 21-22 wanting, dated 1726 on margin of leaf 28A.|Modern foliation in pencil in Arabic numerals.|Recent binding.|Genazym Auction House, catalogue 10, lot 37.|"Tale of the infamous blood libel in Metz, France, 17th century. This Yiddish manuscript recounts, in great detail, the chilling sequence of events of the notorious 17th century blood libel in Metz. The narrative covers Rapha'el Levi's arrest and imprisonment, court proceedings, and the intense efforts taken by French congregational leaders, officers, and community activists to dispel the wrath of the authorities. Part of the story as described in the manuscript was published in Ha-tsofeh Le-hokhmat Yisra'el Vol. 11 (1927) pp.46-65, where it describes the events which transpired up until 28 Tevet. In the present manuscript the tale goes on to recount the events which occurred up until 25 Tammuz."--Auction House catalogue.|Related material shelved in accompanying portfolio.

scribe_as_recorded: Segri, Rianna Miriam de|Segri, Aluvra de
physical_description: Extent: 76 pages ; 26 cm
note: Later cloth binding.|Shelfmark: MS General 322|Manuscript in Hebrew and Italian on paper.|Order of Hakafos for Hoshanah Rabba with Songs for Simchas Torah; manuscript with decorative letters and borders by sisters Rianna Miriam and Aluvra de Segri, daughters of the Segri family, one of the most prestigious Jewish families in Italy; with the titles of each hakafah surrounded in ornamental borders and intricate designs and drawings throughout; title page with inscription: "My book of prayer for Hoshanah Rabba - I, Rianna Miriam and Aluvra de Segri from the city of Saluzzi"; also contains prayers translated to Italian.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Columbia University Rare Book & Manuscript Library
subject_as_recorded: Judaism--Prayers and devotions|Judaism--Liturgy--Texts--19th century|Jews--Italy--19th century
physical_description: Extent: 32 pages ; 12 cm
note: Contemporary full leather binding, decorated.|Shelfmark: MS General 323|Manuscript in Hebrew on paper.|Decorated manuscript from the library of Rabbi Avraham Morpurgo; architectural design on title page, colored in yellow and green, with elaborate pillars and gable, dated "1836" at the base, with words likely added later by Morpurgo at the center of the design; manuscript commences with the prayers recited before counting the Omer; following this, each day of the Omer appears on its own page, each page decorated with a yellow-green colored border; last few pages with prayers recited after counting the Omer; on one of these last pages appears the design of a menorah comprised of the verses of the psalm, "Lamenatse'ah be-neginot mizmor shir"; in original binding, including the original 'forsatz' pages.

physical_description: Extent: 1 leaf : Parchment, ill. ; 79 x 47 cm
note: An arch frames the text. It is surrounded by abundant vegetal tendrils and animals that are swathed between small inserts of the twelve signs of the Zodiac, King David playing the lyre, Moses holding the Torah, Jacob's dream, the Binding of Isaac, and Adam and Eve.|Shelfmark: MS X893 K51994|Manuscript written on parchment in Sefaradic Square script.|Includes Biblical verses: Gen. 27:28; Is. 62:5; Prov18:22, and Ruth 4:11.|The ketubah includes "tenaim," or "conditions," is the engagement contract detailing the couple's union in friendship, trust and faith.|At the end of the Hebrew text there is additional Italian note which give the groom's name and the civil date (Gregorian). In addition it mentions that there is a copy of the ketubah in the archive of the synagogue.

holding_institution_as_recorded: Columbia University Rare Book & Manuscript Library
title_as_recorded: Minḥa and 'Arvit for weekdays and Shabbat; songs, Kiddush and Havdalah, blessing of the moon, and Hallel
subject_as_recorded: Jews--Iraq--History--19th century
physical_description: Extent: 1], 98 leaves ; 12 cm
note: Minḥa and Arvit for weekdays and Shabbat, with Shir Ha-Shirim and Kabbalat Shabbat; includes: Pataḥ Eliyahu, Minḥa and 'Arvit for weekdays, Shir Ha-Shirim, Kabbalat Shabbat, 'Arvit for Shabbat, piyyutim and Kiddush for Friday night, Birkat Ha-Mazon, Minḥa for Shabbat, Havdalah, blessing of the moon, Amidah prayer for the Three Festivals, and Hallel.|Shelfmark: MS General 334|Complete illuminated manuscript in Hebrew, scribed and decorated throughout; pocket format; semi-cursive, square Oriental script; enlarged, decorated initials, with floral ornaments in various colors; each page of text enclosed in a border; additional ornaments.|"Carpet page" on the first page, with a La-Menatze'aḥ Menorah in the center, containing the name of the scribe and year of writing: Ezra Tsion Menashe Aharon Shlomo Yitsḥak Eliya Sofer, 1897. Additional "carpet page" on the final page, stating the name of the scribe. Additional inscription on p. 37a: "Tsion Sofer". A few of the ornaments were colored in watercolor, while most were colored in colored pencils or pastel colors (perhaps at a later date). [1], 98 leaves (late foliation, in pencil)|Original leather binding, with leather clasps|Reference: 1. The 'Shiviti - Menorah', dissertation by Esther Juhasz. Jerusalem, 2004, p. 435 (Hebrew). 2. 101 Sacred Hebrew Songs, edited by Yair Harel and Uri Kroizer. Jerusalem, the Hebrew University, [2017], p. 26 and p. 88.|Provenance: Kedem Auction House, Jerusalem, Israel ; The Gross Family Collection, Tel Aviv, IQ.011.002.

title_as_recorded: Divre Ha-Yamim : [manuscript; historical treatise of Prague
subject_as_recorded: Rabbis--Czech Republic--Prague|Jews--Czech Republic--History--18th century|Prague (Czech Republic)--History
note: ff. 22|Shelfmark: MS General 261|Manuscript in Hebrew, written in a cursive Ashkenazic hand on paper. Title-page incorporating engraved border (detached). Contemporary gilt-tooled calf binding, gold edged, rubbed.|Autobiographical treatise. Recounts family life and the author's relationship with Prague's rabbinic leaders (the Noda Be-Yehuda especially). Written following a severe illness that afflicted Poppers. He here recounts his resolutions for leading a healthier life. The Poppers Family were distinguished throughout the 17th and 18th centuries and provided Europe with many significant rabbinic and communal leaders.|Kestenbaum & Company, New York, sale 65 (Fine Judaica, Printed Books, Manuscripts, Ceremonial Objects and Graphic Art), lot 44, Thursday, June 25, 2015.
